articles.headline: Without Services, Small Businesses Feel the Pinch
articles.snippet: Owners whose companies depend on government services such as a guaranteed loan, regulatory approval or a national park’s operation worry about the toll the shut down may have on them.
articles.abstract: Owners whose companies depend on government services such as a guaranteed loan, regulatory approval or a national park’s operation worry about the toll the shut down may have on them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chris Leh, the owner of a fledgling manufacturing company in Ephrata, Pa., recently landed the kind of deal that growing companies dream about, with a major client whose order volume will triple his annual sales to around $1.5 million.

articles.headline: Fears for Economy Kept Stimulus Intact
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve was close to starting to ease its stimulus campaign, the minutes of its September meeting show.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve was close to starting to ease its stimulus campaign, the minutes of its September meeting show.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The decision by Federal Reserve officials last month to continue the stimulus campaign came down to this: their anxiety that the economy might falter outweighed their anxiety that waiting to pull back would surprise and confuse investors.

articles.headline: Silver Screen and LEDs Join at Last
articles.snippet: A test run looks at seven LED projectors costing $1,000 or less, some that could fit in a pocket and some with bigger ambitions.
articles.abstract: A test run looks at seven LED projectors costing $1,000 or less, some that could fit in a pocket and some with bigger ambitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: The world is discovering LED lights, and for good reason. They last 25 times as long as regular bulbs, they use a fraction of the power, they don’t get as hot and they’re very rugged. They’re cropping up everywhere: in homes, flashlights, car headlights, flat-panel TV screens, movie lights and Christmas lights.

articles.headline: Government Standoff Shakes Trust in U.S. Debt
articles.snippet: Investors are growing wary of the government’s ability to pay its debt in a timely fashion after Oct. 17, shifting the market for short-term Treasury bills and potentially having long-term effects.
articles.abstract: Investors are growing wary of the government’s ability to pay its debt in a timely fashion after Oct. 17, shifting the market for short-term Treasury bills and potentially having long-term effects.
articles.lead_paragraph: In good times and bad, the world’s financial system has long been able to rely on one thing: that the United States government would pay back its debt on time.

articles.headline: The Yellen Fed? Precise and Predictable
articles.snippet: Wall Street investors hope that a Federal Reserve under Janet L. Yellen will telegraph its intentions to the markets, particularly as it tapers efforts to kindle growth.
articles.abstract: Wall Street investors hope that a Federal Reserve under Janet L. Yellen will telegraph its intentions to the markets, particularly as it tapers efforts to kindle growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are no fast rules for running the Federal Reserve, but Janet L. Yellen has a few.

articles.headline: Business Groups See Loss of Sway Over House G.O.P.
articles.snippet: Washington’s traditionally cautious and pragmatic business lobby could slip into open warfare with the Tea Party faction of the Republican Party amid frustration over the crisis.
articles.abstract: Washington’s traditionally cautious and pragmatic business lobby could slip into open warfare with the Tea Party faction of the Republican Party amid frustration over the crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the government shutdown grinds toward a potential debt default, some of the country’s most influential business executives have come to a conclusion all but unthinkable a few years ago: Their voices are carrying little weight with the House majority that their millions of dollars in campaign contributions helped build and sustain.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton, Nicholas Confessore and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: A Novel Prompts a Conversation About How We Use Technology
articles.snippet: Book critics are divided over the quality of Dave Eggers’s highly anticipated novel “The Circle,” which has started a debate on whether technology is invading our lives.
articles.abstract: Book critics are divided over the quality of Dave Eggers’s highly anticipated novel “The Circle,” which has started a debate on whether technology is invading our lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: Has Dave Eggers written a parable of our time, an eviscerating takedown of Silicon Valley and its privacy-invading technology companies?
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Extremist Group Gains Foothold Among Kenyans
articles.snippet: Kenya’s slums have long provided a fertile recruiting ground for Muslim extremists, but analysts say that the Shabab have been finding recruits from across the country, not just in traditionally Muslim areas.
articles.abstract: Kenya’s slums have long provided a fertile recruiting ground for Muslim extremists, but analysts say that the Shabab have been finding recruits from across the country, not just in traditionally Muslim areas.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — When the United States tried to capture a powerful militant in Somalia last weekend, it did not go after the leader of the Shabab extremist group, but a Kenyan national whose ties were as much in his native country as in the Horn of Africa.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish and Josh Kron

articles.headline: Show of Power by Libya Militia in Kidnapping
articles.snippet: The kidnapping and release of Prime Minister Ali Zeidan on Thursday underscored the unrivaled authority of militias in Libya after the fall of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.
articles.abstract: The kidnapping and release of Prime Minister Ali Zeidan on Thursday underscored the unrivaled authority of militias in Libya after the fall of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUNIS — Libya’s prime minister, Ali Zeidan, was hauled from his bed at 2:30 a.m. Thursday by a group of militiamen who stormed into the luxury hotel where he lives in downtown Tripoli, a kidnapping that would be extraordinary by almost any standard.

articles.headline: At Risk: Currency Privilege of the Dollar
articles.snippet: The United States has the credibility to borrow from foreign investors in a currency it can print and under laws it can change, but a default could jeopardize that.
articles.abstract: The United States has the credibility to borrow from foreign investors in a currency it can print and under laws it can change, but a default could jeopardize that.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not all government debt is created equal. Some governments get a much better deal than others, and no one gets a better deal than the United States.

articles.headline: No Quick Deal, but Offer by G.O.P. on Debt Shifts the Tone
articles.snippet: President Obama and House Republicans failed to reach agreement on a short extension of the nation’s borrowing authority during a White House meeting, but both sides agreed to keep talking.
articles.abstract: President Obama and House Republicans failed to reach agreement on a short extension of the nation’s borrowing authority during a White House meeting, but both sides agreed to keep talking.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama and House Republicans failed to reach agreement on a six-week extension of the nation’s borrowing authority during a meeting Thursday at the White House, but the two sides kept talking, and the offer from politically besieged Republicans was seen as an initial step toward ending the budget standoff.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Ashley Parker
